newsitem.title: ETHIOPIA: Zimbabwe to unveil new reform plans by May.
newsitem.headline: Zimbabwe to unveil new reform plans by May.

text.p: Zimbabwe will launch a new phase of economic reforms by May designed to win IMF backing and restore suspended balance of payments support, Finance Minister Herbert Murerwa said on Tuesday.
He told Reuters in Addis Ababa the International Monetary Fund and Zimbabwe were still at odds over Zimbabwe's large budget deficit but measures were being taken to address "that sticking point".

"The IMF visited my country and we have held positive discussions on measures to improve our economy. Further consultations are going on," Murerwa said on the sidelines of a conference of African finance ministers.
"Measures have been thought out to address the sticking question of a large budget deficit. But our economy is alive and well," he added.
He said gross domestic product growth was 8.1 percent in 1995/96 and forecast slower growth of about 5.0 percent in 1996/97.
Murerwa said Zimbabwe had no misunderstandings with the IMF and was anxious to see a resumption of balance of payments support, which was suspended about two years ago.
"We hope that aid resumption can come soon. Both sides have shown good intentions in the discussions and we would be happy to see a speedy conclusion of the negotiations," Murerwa said.
He said Zimbabwe was working on a programme of "home-grown and unique economic reforms" which he hoped would win the backing of the World Bank and the IMF.
The reforms to be launched in a month included measures to streamline and strengthen fiscal policy, further privatisation and public service reform.
He would not say how many civil service jobs would be cut or which public companies Zimbabwe planned to sell first.
Murerwa said a new trade agreement with South Africa to replace one which was signed in 1964 and expired two years ago was expected "very soon" but he did not say when.
He said South Africa and Zimbabwe had already agreed on tariff reductions on several sectors, including textiles, and that South Africa was not an obstacle to the treaty.
"There already is an agreement. It is really just a matter of time before the trade treaty is signed. I cannot put a date to it but it will be very soon," he said.
He said Zimbabwe was not very impressed by a new international debt initiative that aims to reduce total debt for the most indebted and poorest countries on the globe.
He said a six-year track record of economic reform success was too long and eligibility criteria were suspect.
"With the current criteria, there aren't many African countries that qualify. Zimbabwe does not and no southern African country does," he said.
